headline.seo: Richmond, Calif., Seeks to Tax Sweetened Beverages
headline.print_headline: Plan to Tax Soda Gets a Mixed Reception
headline.main: Plan to Tax Soda Gets a Mixed Reception

docs.abstract: Richmond journal; proposed one-cent-per-ounce tax on sugar-sweetened beverages sold in Richmond, Calif, which has double the national poverty rate, is the most visible West Coast municipal challenge yet to soda; tax money would go toward fighting childhood obesity; tax proposal, to appear on the November ballot, is being viewed as a beachhead by a coalition of beverage makers, merchant groups and labor unions who are organizing to defeat it.
docs.lead_paragraph: The link between obesity and poverty is close and complicated, as leaders in one city learned when they tried to make high-calorie beverages more expensive.
docs.snippet: The link between obesity and poverty is close and complicated, as leaders in one city learned when they tried to make high-calorie beverages more expensive.

headline.main: What's the Best Way to Break Society's Bad Habits?

docs.abstract: Is it the government's role to change people's behavior and make them live healthier lives? And if so, what's the most effective way to do it?
docs.snippet: Is it the government's role to change people's behavior and make them live healthier lives? And if so, what's the most effective way to do it?

headline.seo: Soda Industry Maps Campaign to Defeat Bloomberg Plan
headline.print_headline: Soda Industry Maps Strategy to Defeat Bloomberg Plan to Ban Super-Size Drinks
headline.main: Soda Industry Maps Strategy to Defeat Bloomberg Plan to Ban Super-Size Drinks

docs.abstract: Soda industry was blindsided by New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's proposal to ban the sale of large-sized sweetened beverages at virtually all of the city's restaurants, street carts and theaters; an army of lobbyists and researchers are scrambling to plan a counterattack that could include a fight at the state legislative level, or even court.
docs.lead_paragraph: Lobbyists and researchers who have proven adept at combating other government regulatory efforts find themselves scrambling to counterattack the mayor’s proposal.
docs.snippet: Lobbyists and researchers who have proven adept at combating other government regulatory efforts find themselves scrambling to counterattack the mayor’s proposal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sampling the many responses to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s new plan in New York City.
docs.snippet: Sampling the many responses to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s new plan in New York City.

headline.main: Prohibitions by the People, for the People

docs.abstract: City Room blog; readers submit suggestions for possible bans in New York City in light of Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's proposed ban on the sale of large sugary drinks at restaurants and other outlets. Drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: New York may be the world's greatest city, but it abounds with menaces to the public health and well-being. So when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed banning the sale of large sugary drinks at restaurants and other places, City Room took the opportunity to ask readers to suggest other things that ought not to be allowed. Here are a few of the nearly 300 substances, practices and persons you earmarked for prohibition. For which we thank you.

headline.main: Fill-In | New York City's Plan to Outlaw Enormous Sugary Drinks

docs.abstract: Can you fill in the 18 words missing from the first several paragraphs of the article "New York Plans to Ban Sale of Big Sizes of Sugary Drinks"?
docs.snippet: Can you fill in the 18 words missing from the first several paragraphs of the article "New York Plans to Ban Sale of Big Sizes of Sugary Drinks"?

docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg for overreaching with his plan to limit the sale of large size sugary drinks; holds administration should instead be focusing on programs that educate and encourage people to make sound choices.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Bloomberg has done a lot to improve public health, but he overreaches with a new plan to limit the sale of large size sugary drinks.
docs.snippet: Mayor Bloomberg has done a lot to improve public health, but he overreaches with a new plan to limit the sale of large size sugary drinks.

headline.seo: To Gulp or to Sip? Debating a Crackdown on Big Sugary Drinks
headline.print_headline: To Gulp or to Sip? Debating a Crackdown On Big Sugary Drinks
headline.main: To Gulp or to Sip? Debating a Crackdown on Big Sugary Drinks

byline.contributor: Michael M. Grynbaum and Alex Vadukul contributed reporting.

docs.abstract: New Yorkers react to Mayor Michael R Bloomberg's proposed ban prohibiting the sale of any cup or bottle of sugar-sweetened drink larger than 16 fluid ounces.
docs.lead_paragraph: Some New Yorkers took it hard when they learned the mayor wanted to take away their plus-size sodas.
docs.snippet: Some New Yorkers took it hard when they learned the mayor wanted to take away their plus-size sodas.
